content.question: A car on a straight road is at rest at position <math alttext="x equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> from time <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> to <math alttext="t equals 1 second" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>. At <math alttext="t equals 5 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, the car is at position <math alttext="x equals 40 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>40</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>, and at time <math alttext="t equals 10 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math>, the car is at position <math alttext="x equals 80 meters" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>80</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">m</mi></math>. Is the average velocity of the car between <math alttext="t equals 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0</mn></math> and <math alttext="t equals 5 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> less than the average velocity of the car between <math alttext="t equals 5 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>5</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> and <math alttext="t equals 10 seconds" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>10</mn><mo> </mo><mi mathvariant="normal">s</mi></math> ? Why or why not?

choices.label: Yes, because the car has zero velocity for part of the first time interval.
Yes, because the acceleration of the car is less during the first time interval.
No, because the car travels the same distance over the same amount of time in both intervals.
No, because the car had to go faster in the first time interval since it was at rest for the first second.

content.answer: No, because the car travels the same distance over the same amount of time in both intervals.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
